title: William D. Foster
description: William D. Foster (1860-1940) was a late 19th- early 20th-century film producer. In 1910, he founded the first African American production company in Chicago, Illinois, the Foster Photoplay Company. Foster wanted to challenge the negative images of African Americans so often seen in films made by white film producers. The Foster Photoplay Company produced The Railroad Porter (1913), which is believed to be the first film made with an all Black cast and director. Aiming to bring positive Black representation on screen to filmgoers, Williams Foster steadily produced several more films through his production company before closing in 1917.
subject: African American; Silent films

title: By Right of Birth (embedded clip, The Trooper with Troop K)
description:
The Lincoln Motion Picture Company was founded by brothers Noble Johnson (1881-1978) and George Perry Johnson (1885-1977) in 1916 in Omaha, Nebraska. The company moved to Los Angeles, California, shortly afterward. Like their predecessor, William D. Foster, the Johnson brothers wanted to create moving pictures specifically for Black audiences. They produced five films, which included "The Realization of a Negro's Ambition" (1916), "The Law of Nature" (1916), "The Trooper of Company K" (1917), "A Man's Duty" (1919), and "By Right of Birth" (1921). "By Right of Birth" was the last film produced before operations ceased shortly afterward. 

All films produced by The Lincoln Motion Picture were thought to be lost except for pieces of "By Right of Birth." However, in 2022, a professor at Indiana University in Bloomington, Cara Caddoo, solved a strange occurrence that happened in the film "By Right of Birth." The total length of the film is about four minutes. Around the 2:28 mark of the film, a 15-second clip of another movie can be seen in the top left corner of the picture. The phantom clip was a mystery until Cara Caddoo recognized Noble Johnson. Noble Johnson, Caddoo learned, was in the film "The Trooper of Company K." A fragment of the film "The Trooper of Company K," thought lost forever, was superimposed in "By Right of Birth." 

In this 30-second clip from "By Right of Birth," the superimposed fragments from "The Trooper of Company K" can be seen 2 seconds into the clip.
creator: Grant, Harry; Johnson, George P.; Johnson, Noble, Brooks, Clarence, Jones, Beullah Hall; The Lincoln Motion Picture Company
subject: African American; Silent films

title: Bert Williams
description: Bert Williams (1874-1922) was a successful Bahamian-born American performer. He frequently performed in vaudeville acts and films alongside George W. Walker (1872-1911). Williams often performed in blackface, for which he received some criticism. During early cinema, it was required for at least one Black actor to dress in blackface, which allowed other Black actors on set to perform without it.
creator: Samuel Lumiere
subject: African American; Silent films

title: Something Good
description: "Something Good-Negro Kiss" shows two African American actors, Saint Suttle (1870-1932), and Gertie Brown (1878-1934), happily smiling, embracing, and sharing kisses. Allyson Nadia Field, an Associate Professor of Cinema and Media Studies at the University of Chicago, discovered the short 29-second clip in 2017. The short clip is significant in African American film history because it is the earliest depiction of affection involving African American Actors.  The second clip of what may be an additional part of the film was found in a barn in Norway and then sent to the National Library of Norway. Researchers there examined the 49-second clip and connected it to the same film found in the US.
creator: Selig, William; Suttle, Saint; Brown, Gertie; Selig Polyscope Company
subject: African American; Silent films

title: The Crescent Theatre Newspaper Adverstisement
description: The Crescent was a short lived vaudeville and cinema theatre. Located in Harlem, New York, it opened in 1909 with patrons clamouring to get inside. The theatre featured “at least one Vitagraph picture daily”, which were short films about 10-15 minutes long. The theatre did not stay in operation long but it is regarded as one the first moviegoing experiences for African Americans.
creator: The Crescent Theatre
subject: African American; Silent films
